user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_run_from_select:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_run_from_select (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                     const fd_set *read_fd_set,
                     const fd_set *write_fd_set,
                     const fd_set *except_fd_set)
{
  return MHD_run_from_select2 (daemon,
                               read_fd_set,
                               write_fd_set,
                               except_fd_set,
#ifdef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
                               daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app ?
                               ((unsigned int) daemon->fdset_size) :
                               ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#else  /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                               ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                               );
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
                               daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app ?
                               ((unsigned int) daemon->fdset_size) :
                               ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#else  /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                               ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
explanation:
I flagged the macro-based declaration (_MHD_EXTERN) and the preprocessor-controlled FD_SETSIZE selection because macros commonly hide compiler-specific attributes or calling-convention/storage-class extensions (for example __attribute__, __declspec, __stdcall, visibility attributes, etc.). Those macro expansions are the only places in this snippet that could legitimately introduce documented compiler extensions; their definitions must be inspected to determine compliance with MISRA C Rule 1.2.

All other code in the fragment uses standard C constructs: enum return type, function definition syntax, standard pointer and struct usage, fd_set type, conditional (?:) operator, casts to unsigned int, and ordinary preprocessor conditionals — none of these are compiler language extensions as shown. There are no explicit extension tokens visible (for example __attribute__, __declspec, inline assembly, typeof, statement-expressions, labels-as-values, or other known compiler-specific keywords). Therefore no other parts of the snippet need investigation for Rule 1.2.
